tips: Include the whole script into a BEGIN; ... COMMIT; block
Begin the script with DROP SCHEMA IF EXISTS schema_name CASCADE;
Use a unique search_path for each dataset
Group insertions into a single INSERT INTO statement for each table to greatly improve performance

about.title: About LensQL
about.p1: LensQL is an interactive platform that helps students learn SQL through guided practice, personalized feedback, and gamified progression. Built with both students and teachers in mind, it supports a deeper understanding of relational databases by focusing on the reasoning behind queries ‚Äî not just their correctness.
about.p2: Instead of offering immediate solutions, LensQL encourages active exploration. The AI assistant, Lens, helps students reflect on their mistakes, refine their logic, and grow their skills with every attempt. Teachers, meanwhile, gain insight into how students learn, where they struggle, and how to support them effectively.
about.p3: Whether you're running your first query or refining complex joins, LensQL turns every error into an opportunity to learn.
about.moreIntro: LensQL is developed as part of ongoing research at the University of Genoa. If you're curious about the academic background or technical details, here are some publications that explore the ideas behind it:
about.paper1: Analyzing Common Student Errors in SQL Query Formulation to Enhance Learning Support
about.paper1Desc: A large-scale study on student SQL mistakes and how they vary across learning settings.
about.paper2: Enhancing SQL Learning through Generative AI and Student Error Analysis
about.paper2Desc: A framework for AI-assisted feedback, error tracking, and personalized assignment generation in SQL education.

Simple Select.label: Simple SELECT
Simple Select.description: Write a simple SELECT statement to retrieve data from a single table.

Single condition.label: Single condition
Single condition.description: Write queries that filter results based on a single condition.

Distinct.label: DISTINCT
Distinct.description: Use the DISTINCT keyword to eliminate duplicate rows from query results.

Aggregate functions.label: Aggregate functions
Aggregate functions.description: Use aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, and MAX to summarize data.

Subquery in SELECT.label: Subquery in SELECT
Subquery in SELECT.description: Write queries that include subqueries in the SELECT clause.

Case statements.label: CASE statements
Case statements.description: Use CASE statements to create conditional logic within queries.

String functions.label: String functions
String functions.description: Apply string functions to manipulate text data in queries.

Date functions.label: Date functions
Date functions.description: Use date functions to manipulate and format date and time data in queries.

Numeric functions.label: Numeric functions
Numeric functions.description: Apply numeric functions to perform calculations on numeric data in queries.

Window functions.label: Window functions
Window functions.description: Use window functions to perform calculations across a set of rows related to the current row.

Simple join.label: Simple JOIN
Simple join.description: Write queries that involve a simple join between two tables to retrieve related data.

Self join.label: Self JOIN
Self join.description: Write queries that involve self-joins to compare rows within the same table.

Left join.label: LEFT JOIN
Left join.description: Write queries that use LEFT JOIN to retrieve all rows from one table and matching rows from another.

Right join.label: RIGHT JOIN
Right join.description: Write queries that use RIGHT JOIN to retrieve all rows from one table and matching rows from another.

Full outer join.label: FULL OUTER JOIN
Full outer join.description: Use FULL OUTER JOIN to retrieve all rows when there is a match in either table.

Subquery in FROM.label: Subquery in FROM
Subquery in FROM.description: Utilize subqueries in the FROM clause to create derived tables.

Multiple conditions.label: Multiple conditions
Multiple conditions.description: Use logical operators to filter results based on multiple conditions.

Subquery in WHERE.label: Subquery in WHERE
Subquery in WHERE.description: Use subqueries in the WHERE clause to filter results based on related data.

Correlated subqueries.label: Correlated subqueries
Correlated subqueries.description: Write correlated subqueries that reference columns from the outer query.

Group by.label: GROUP BY
Group by.description: Group results using the GROUP BY clause to aggregate data based on specific columns.

Group by with conditions.label: HAVING clause
Group by with conditions.description: Use the HAVING clause to filter grouped results based on aggregate conditions.

Order by.label: ORDER BY
Order by.description: Sort query results using the ORDER BY clause.

Limit and offset.label: LIMIT and OFFSET
Limit and offset.description: Use LIMIT and OFFSET to control the number of rows returned by a query.

Union.label: UNION
Union.description: Combine results from multiple queries using the UNION operator.

Intersect.label: INTERSECT
Intersect.description: Retrieve common results from multiple queries using the INTERSECT operator.

Except.label: EXCEPT
Except.description: Use the EXCEPT operator to find results in one query that are not in another.
